references:
, many different approaches have been proposed to address personalisation and uncertainty quantification under the federated learning paradigm.
This section reviews the main related existing lines of research and shows that the proposed methodology provides many benefits; see
encompasses some of the existing FL models.

One of our main motivations is the possibility to perform grounded uncertainty quantification in FL by resorting to the Bayesian paradigm.
In the recent years, many works have suggested to adapt serial workhorses stochastic simulation approaches such as MCMC or variational inference to the FL setting

.
Although some of these approaches address important FL challenges such as the communication bottleneck, partial participation or limited computational device resources, they are not suitable for uncertainty quantification in the cross-device FL scenario.
Indeed, all these approaches assume that the posterior distribution targeted by each client is parametrised by a single potentially high-dimensional parameter of size
, significantly reducing the memory footprint of local sample storage.
In addition, Bayesian FL methods aim at sampling a random parameter from a target probability distribution where
denotes the negative log-likelihood associated to the

-th client. On the other hand the proposed methodology considers a mixed-effects modeling approach where parameters are divided into two categories: a fixed component and a random one for each client. As such, the mixed-effects approach is in essence an empirical Bayesian/marginal likelihood approach

. It corresponds to a hierarchical model that aims to combine the modeling flexibility and uncertainty assessment of Bayesian inference with computational pragmatism. More precisely, a part of the parameters (fixed-effects ) are estimated via marginal likelihood maximisation and the rest (random effects) using common Bayesian techniques, which are in most cases low dimensional. As a result, up to our knowledge, the model and approach that we propose is novel in FL and comes with many benefits as shown in

Beside uncertainty quantification, we also aim at providing each client with a dedicated personalised model.
Among the numerous existing personalised FL approaches, those related to
can be broadly classified into two groups:

.
Meta-learning based FL methods aim at training a global model conducive to fast training of personalised models. Such a goal can be achieved, for example, by local fine-tuning
, regularisation of local models towards their average

.
On the other hand, FL methods based on partial decoupling take an approach similar to ours by splitting the initial model into a backbone component and a local one aimed at personalisation
. This partial decoupling could also enhance privacy as discussed in
is that such approaches based on empirical risk minimisation cannot provide credibility information.
: A Compromise between Standard and Personalised FL.
Interestingly, we show here that the

framework allows existing FL approaches to be retrieved in certain regimes.
To this end, we assume that the prior
, then this Gaussian prior tends towards the Dirac distribution centered at
, which corresponds to the local objective of standard FL approaches such as
and we end up with the

stands for a subtle compromise between standard and personalised FL which should benefit clients with small data sets by pooling information via a common prior.
Finally, in the extreme scenario where
is the null vector, our approach amounts to the Bayesian FL approach

In this section, we illustrate the benefits of our methodology on several FL benchmarks associated to both synthetic and real data.
Since existing Bayesian FL approaches are not suited for personalisation (see
), we only compare the performances of

with personalised FL methods.
In all our experiments, we use overdamped Langevin dynamics to sample locally and call this specific instance of

for simplicity.
To be comparable with existing personalised FL approaches that only consider periodic communication via multiple local steps, we do not resort to the proposed compression mechanism although the latter could be of interest for real-world applications.
Additional experiments and details about experimental design are provided in the supplement.

In addition to show that the proposed approach achieves state-of-the-art performances on small data sets (which is common in the cross-device scenario), we now illustrate that

is also competitive on larger data sets.
To this end, we use all training images in CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 image data sets and consider the same data partitioning as in

.
More precisely, in this case the number of observations and the number of classes per client are uniformly shared over the clients.

shows our results in comparison with state-of-the-art personalised FL approaches.
We can see that that our model outperforms other methods on both CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 by a large margin.
Additional results with other personalised FL algorithms are postponed to the supplement.
, one advantage of the proposed approach compared to existing personalised FL methods is the ability to perform uncertainty quantification by sampling locally from the posterior

.
We illustrate this feature by computing on CIFAR-10 calibration curves and scores (
expected calibration error aka ECE) on a specific client; and by performing an out-of-distribution analysis on MNIST/FashionMNIST data sets.

shows that the proposed approach provides relevant uncertainty diagnosis.
Additional results on uncertainty quantification can be found in the supplement.
